name: 李老师不是你老师
content: On September 11, Renjing.com published an article by He Xuefeng, Dean of the School of Social Sciences at Wuhan University, titled "Why has targeted poverty alleviation fallen into formalism?" The article states that the author visited and investigated seven villages in two townships and found that the real poor households in the villages came from families with no labor force due to serious illness or disability. Such families, no matter how much effort they put in, still have to rely on social security to provide a safety net in the end. As a result, in the past five years, in order to accurately target households and individuals for targeted poverty alleviation, almost all administrative and financial resources of counties, towns and villages have been occupied. Most of these resources have been wasted on infinitely complicated formalisms that should not be done to meet inspections and to conform to logic.

content:
Qin Hui, a retired professor of history at Tsinghua University, expressed his views on the issue of delaying the retirement age in his latest video:
A limited government only bears limited responsibilities. You have unlimited power, so why should your responsibilities be limited? When it comes to responsibilities, you compare yourself with Europe and the United States, but not when it comes to power.
If you can't bear such a big responsibility, what reason do you have to have such a big power? The extension of power to the womb is a Chinese characteristic. Shouldn't unlimited pension responsibility also be a Chinese characteristic?

On September 13, an article published 11 years ago in China Youth Daily, "Delaying retirement may be a breach of contract for a generation," was removed from the shelves.
The article mentioned that on the issue of pension, the dual-track system should be changed first, and then delayed retirement should be discussed; government investment should be increased first, and then public responsibility should be discussed. Fairness should come first, and efficiency second.
